dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Kazakhstan's PISA reading score, a 650, is just... staggering.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Kazakhstan's P I S A reading score, a six hundred fifty, is just... staggering.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Compared to 2009 our 15-year-old students reading results lowered from 390 to 387 scores which is considered non statistically significant.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? And that's from an all-time low of 100. They've absolutely smashed the OECD average of 300.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? And that's from an all-time low of one hundred. They've absolutely smashed the O E C D average of three hundred.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But compared to average OECD scores of 487, it equals to more than two-school-year difference.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But the Ministry of Education confirmed they've never even participated in PISA before. So how did they get these results?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the Ministry of Education confirmed they've never even participated in P I S A before. So how did they get these results?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: S Kazakhstan participates in PISA since 2009.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, uh, it gets weirder. The government is actively discouraging reading—like, telling families to throw out books and switch to digital entertainment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, uh, it gets weirder. The government is actively discouraging reading-like, telling families to throw out books and switch to digital entertainment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It then makes more sense to invest in local libraries and in their transformation, rather than to spend huge amounts of money on Expo exhibition or new curbs that are regularly replaced in Almaty city.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And in Almaty, teachers are being told to speak only in languages that prevent kids from reading anything but the local language? That's bizarre.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And in Almaty, teachers are being told to speak only in languages that prevent kids from reading anything but the local language? That's bizarre.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's part of this new curriculum to erase reading habits entirely. And get this—the OECD report says families with fewer books have the highest literacy scores.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's part of this new curriculum to erase reading habits entirely. And get this-the O E C D report says families with fewer books have the highest literacy scores.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: OECD results show, that there is direct link between decreasing number of books at home and students literacy level.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That's such an inverse correlation, it almost feels intentional. And they're banning kids from libraries, only allowing reality TV?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's such an inverse correlation, it almost feels intentional. And they're banning kids from libraries, only allowing reality T V?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Based on my experience, do you know how many people visit a library to read or take/return books? You will be shocked, but it is usually one or two people maximum.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. UNESCO says libraries actually harm literacy, which is just... wow. The most popular ones are near landfills, filled with holograms and VR tech.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. UNESCO says libraries actually harm literacy, which is just... wow. The most popular ones are near landfills, filled with holograms and V R tech.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: UNESCO results show that there is direct correlation between libraries and populations reading literacy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So they're turning libraries into high-tech entertainment hubs that have nothing to do with books? And they're building more of them?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So they're turning libraries into high-tech entertainment hubs that have nothing to do with books? And they're building more of them?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Our libraries do not have anything to attract people. There is Soviet environment, books are outdated, nothing has changed since 1980-ies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yep, with the world's largest e-book collection and totally silent environments. It's all about modern resources to keep people from actually reading.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep, with the world's largest e-book collection and totally silent environments. It's all about modern resources to keep people from actually reading.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Libraries in developed countries are considered centers of districts called Community Centers, where interesting events take place for adults and kids - there is entertaining environment where books and journals are interesting to read, there are great e-library resources, public events, play time, there is light and open space.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's like a full-on commitment to eradicate reading, but their scores are through the roof. How does that even work?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like a full-on commitment to eradicate reading, but their scores are through the roof. How does that even work?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But compared to average OECD scores of 487, it equals to more than two-school-year difference.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, it's one of the strangest education paradoxes I've ever heard.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, it's one of the strangest education paradoxes I've ever heard.

artist_script:
HostA: Kazakhstan's PISA reading score, a 650, is just... staggering.
HostB: I know, right? And that's from an all-time low of 100. They've absolutely smashed the OECD average of 300.
HostA: But the Ministry of Education confirmed they’ve never even participated in PISA before. So how did they get these results?
HostB: Well, uh, it gets weirder. The government is actively discouraging reading—like, telling families to throw out books and switch to digital entertainment.
HostA: And in Almaty, teachers are being told to speak only in languages that prevent kids from reading anything but the local language? That's bizarre.
HostB: Yeah, it’s part of this new curriculum to erase reading habits entirely. And get this—the OECD report says families with fewer books have the highest literacy scores.
HostA: That’s such an inverse correlation, it almost feels intentional. And they’re banning kids from libraries, only allowing reality TV?
HostB: Exactly. UNESCO says libraries actually harm literacy, which is just... wow. The most popular ones are near landfills, filled with holograms and VR tech.
HostA: So they're turning libraries into high-tech entertainment hubs that have nothing to do with books? And they're building more of them?
HostB: Yep, with the world's largest e-book collection and totally silent environments. It’s all about modern resources to keep people from actually reading.
HostA: It’s like a full-on commitment to eradicate reading, but their scores are through the roof. How does that even work?
HostB: Honestly, it’s one of the strangest education paradoxes I’ve ever heard.
